radiographic_examinations.findings: Possible small, fixed, apical–inferior myocardial infarct surrounded by an area of mild ischemia; a small, posterobasal septal, nontransmural infarct with apical hypokinesis.

radiographic_examinations.date: Four months before the main examination
radiographic_examinations.findings: Segmental left ventricular apical hypokinesis or akinesis; small pericardial effusion.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Showed a multilobular mass of echoes (4.3 by 3.1 cm) invading the tricuspid annulus and right ventricular free wall with moderate pericardial effusion three and a half months later.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Large, lobulated, slightly oblong mass projecting into the right atrial cavity, with maximal diameter ranging from 5.9 to 7.0 cm, merging with myocardium of the right and left ventricles.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: The mass appeared to protrude partially into the tricuspid orifice without thrombus formation.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Dense infiltrate of large atypical lymphoid cells consistent with aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that was EBV-positive.

radiographic_examinations.date: Eight weeks after the start of chemotherapy
radiographic_examinations.findings: The pedunculated, lobulated right atrial mass decreased in size to 1.7 by 3.0 cm, no longer obstructing the tricuspid valve, with the pericardium appearing free of disease.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Ejection fraction decreased from 60 percent to 45 percent after chemotherapy.
